Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Microfabricated Platform with Integrated Optical Fibers for Photostimulation Studies of Neural Tissue

POR.DRECONTENT:
A novel device has been made for use with in vitro optogenetic tissue research. This device consists of an array of fiber holders for optical fibers that lead to an inclined mirror that directs light from the horizontal incoming fibers upwards at a right angle to the target above. This new tool allows researchers to specifically control the spatio and temporal aspects of light stimulation in a manner that is cheap and easy to use. A new fabrication process was developed as a result of the research. This device allows researchers to conduct new experiments with neurobiological tissues and so advance the understanding of neurological functions, potentially uncovering knowledge that leads to alleviation of neurological diseases. This device may also have applications in the field of synthetic biology in which gene regulation within tissues and cells are controlled by light. This device may also be used for biomechanics research in which a side view image of the cell as it is deformed mechanically can be obtained, something which is not possible with current microscopes.

 

Through this research, international relationships with other researchers in the field have been established. This research has also given mentorship and research opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students. A neuroscience doctoral student managed to gain experience working with sterile cell culture techniques and optogenetics. Two undergraduate students independently performed a literature search and created a protocol for cell culturing. As a result of the research experience and knowledge gained, one is pursuing graduate studies in public health and the other is launching a career in a biomedical device company.
